title: Kings of Israel and Judah
shortSummary: 2 Kings 15 chronicles the reigns of several kings of Israel and Judah, highlighting their faithfulness or unfaithfulness to God. The chapter reveals a pattern of political intrigue, idolatry, and divine judgment, alongside moments of righteousness and God's sovereign control over history.
timeline: c. 800-740 BC - Period of the Divided Kingdom during the reigns of Israel and Judah's kings

keyCharacters.name: Azariah (Uzziah)
keyCharacters.description: King of Judah who reigned 52 years, generally did right in the eyes of the LORD but did not remove the high places; afflicted with leprosy.

keyCharacters.name: Zachariah
keyCharacters.description: Son of Jeroboam, king of Israel for six months; continued evil practices and was assassinated.

keyCharacters.name: Menahem
keyCharacters.description: King of Israel who reigned 10 years; known for cruelty and paying tribute to Assyria to secure his throne.

keyCharacters.name: Pekah
keyCharacters.description: King of Israel who reigned 20 years; continued the sins of Jeroboam and faced Assyrian invasions.

keyCharacters.name: Jotham
keyCharacters.description: Son of Azariah, king of Judah who did right but did not remove high places; faced threats from Syria and Israel.

outline.heading: Azariah’s Reign in Judah
outline.description: Azariah (Uzziah) begins his reign at 16, ruling 52 years and doing right before the LORD, but failing to remove high places. His leprosy leads to his isolation and the delegation of authority to his son Jotham.

outline.heading: Rapid Succession of Israel’s Kings
outline.description: Israel experiences political instability with assassinations and short reigns of kings Zachariah, Shallum, Menahem, and Pekahiah, all continuing in evil ways, reflecting the nation’s spiritual decline.

outline.heading: Menahem’s Brutality and Tribute to Assyria
outline.description: Menahem brutally suppresses opposition and secures his throne by paying heavy tribute to Pul, king of Assyria, illustrating the political pressures Israel faced and the cost of disobedience.

outline.heading: Pekah’s Reign and Assyrian Invasion
outline.description: Pekah reigns 20 years, continuing Israel’s sins. During his reign, Tiglathpileser of Assyria conquers northern territories and carries captives away, signaling divine judgment through foreign powers.

outline.heading: Jotham’s Reign in Judah
outline.description: Jotham reigns 16 years, following his father’s righteous example but failing to remove high places. His reign faces external threats from Syria and Israel, setting the stage for future challenges.

application: Remain faithful to God’s commands fully, not partially, as Azariah’s failure to remove high places shows the danger of incomplete obedience.
Recognize that political or social instability often reflects spiritual decline; believers should pray for godly leadership and remain steadfast in faith.
Trust God’s sovereignty even when facing external threats or personal trials, as seen in the reigns of Judah’s kings who faced Assyrian and Syrian aggression.
Avoid the temptation to compromise with evil for personal gain, exemplified by Menahem’s brutal tactics and alliance with Assyria.

keyVerses.text: And he did that which was right in the sight of the LORD, according to all that his father Amaziah had done;
keyVerses.significance: Highlights the importance of following godly examples and doing what is right before God.

keyVerses.text: Save that the high places were not removed: the people sacrificed and burnt incense still on the high places.
keyVerses.significance: Shows that incomplete obedience leads to ongoing idolatry and displeasure with God.

keyVerses.text: And he did that which was evil in the sight of the LORD: he departed not all his days from the sins of Jeroboam the son of Nebat, who made Israel to sin.
keyVerses.significance: Emphasizes the persistent sinfulness of Israel’s kings and the consequences of following sinful predecessors.

keyVerses.text: In the days of Pekah king of Israel came Tiglathpileser king of Assyria, and took Ijon, and Abelbethmaachah, and Janoah, and Kedesh, and Hazor, and Gilead, and Galilee, all the land of Naphtali, and carried them captive to Assyria.
keyVerses.significance: Illustrates God’s judgment through foreign powers against Israel for their persistent disobedience.
